canonical_explanation.text: Carbon is a versatile element that forms a vast number of compounds due to its tetravalency (ability to form four bonds) and catenation (ability to bond with other carbon atoms to form long chains, branched chains, and rings). Carbon forms covalent bonds by sharing electrons. Saturated hydrocarbons (alkanes) contain only single bonds, while unsaturated hydrocarbons contain double bonds (alkenes) or triple bonds (alkynes). A homologous series is a family of compounds with the same general formula, similar chemical properties, and a constant difference of CH2 between successive members. Functional groups like -OH (alcohol), -COOH (carboxylic acid), and -CHO (aldehyde) determine the chemical properties of organic compounds. Ethanol and ethanoic acid are two important carbon compounds with wide applications. Soaps and detergents are sodium or potassium salts of long-chain fatty acids that clean by forming micelles.
rules: Carbon has a valency of 4 (tetravalent) and forms covalent bonds by sharing electrons.
Catenation is the ability of carbon to form bonds with other carbon atoms.
Saturated hydrocarbons (alkanes) have only single C-C bonds; general formula CnH2n+2.
Unsaturated hydrocarbons have double bonds (alkenes, CnH2n) or triple bonds (alkynes, CnH2n-2).
Allotropes of carbon: diamond (hard, 3D network), graphite (soft, layered), fullerene (spherical).
Homologous series members differ by -CH2- and have similar chemical properties.
IUPAC names: root word (chain length) + suffix (functional group).
Combustion of carbon compounds produces CO2 and H2O.
Addition reactions: unsaturated -> saturated by adding H2/halogen.
Soaps form micelles that trap oily dirt; detergents work in hard water too.

questions.question_text: Carbon forms covalent bonds because it:

options.text: Shares electrons to achieve noble gas configuration

questions.explanation_correct: Carbon forms covalent bonds by sharing electrons. It has 4 valence electrons and needs 4 more to complete its octet. Gaining 4 electrons would make the atom highly negatively charged, and losing 4 would require too much energy. Sharing is the most stable option.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gaining 4 electrons (A) would give the atom a charge of 4-, which is very unstable. Losing 4 electrons (B) would require enormous energy. Carbon does form bonds (D is wrong). Sharing electrons through covalent bonding is the energetically favourable option for carbon.

questions.question_text: The valency of carbon is:
questions.explanation_correct: The valency of carbon is 4 (it is tetravalent). Carbon has 4 electrons in its outermost shell (electronic configuration: 2, 4) and needs 4 more electrons to achieve a stable octet. Therefore, it can form 4 covalent bonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbon does not have a valency of 2 (A), 3 (B), or 5 (D). With an electronic configuration of 2, 4, carbon has exactly 4 valence electrons, giving it a valency of 4. This tetravalency is key to its versatile bonding.

questions.question_text: The ability of carbon to form bonds with other carbon atoms is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Catenation is the unique ability of carbon to form bonds with other carbon atoms, resulting in long chains, branched chains, and ring structures. This property, combined with tetravalency, is why carbon forms such a large number of compounds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tetravalency (A) refers to carbon's ability to form four bonds. Isomerism (C) refers to compounds with the same molecular formula but different structures. Polymerisation (D) is the process of forming large molecules from smaller units. Catenation specifically refers to self-linking of carbon atoms.

questions.question_text: Which allotrope of carbon is used as a lubricant?
questions.explanation_correct: Graphite is used as a lubricant because it has a layered structure where the layers can slide over each other easily. Each carbon atom in graphite is bonded to three other carbon atoms in flat hexagonal layers, with weak forces between the layers allowing them to slip.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diamond (A) is extremely hard and is used for cutting tools, not as a lubricant. Fullerene (C) is a spherical molecule used in research. Charcoal (D) is amorphous carbon used as fuel. Graphite's slippery layered structure makes it ideal as a lubricant.

questions.question_text: Covalent compounds generally have:
questions.explanation_correct: Covalent compounds generally have low melting and boiling points because the intermolecular forces between their molecules are weak. Unlike ionic compounds with strong electrostatic forces, covalent molecules are held together by relatively weak van der Waals forces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: High melting and boiling points (A) are characteristic of ionic compounds. Covalent compounds are generally poor conductors of electricity (C is wrong). Most covalent compounds are insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents (D is wrong).

questions.question_text: Saturated hydrocarbons contain:

options.text: Only double bonds between carbon atoms
Only triple bonds between carbon atoms
Only single bonds between carbon atoms

questions.explanation_correct: Saturated hydrocarbons (alkanes) contain only single bonds between carbon atoms. They are called 'saturated' because each carbon atom is bonded to the maximum number of hydrogen atoms possible. Their general formula is CnH2n+2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Double bonds (A) are found in alkenes (unsaturated). Triple bonds (B) are found in alkynes (unsaturated). A mix of single and double bonds (D) would make the compound unsaturated. Saturated means all C-C bonds are single bonds.

questions.question_text: The general formula of alkenes is:
questions.explanation_correct: The general formula of alkenes is CnH2n. Alkenes are unsaturated hydrocarbons that contain at least one carbon-carbon double bond. For example, ethene (C2H4) has the formula C2H2(2) = C2H4, which follows CnH2n where n=2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CnH2n+2 (A) is the general formula of alkanes (saturated hydrocarbons). CnH2n-2 (C) is the formula for alkynes. CnHn (D) is not a standard formula. Alkenes with one double bond follow CnH2n.

questions.question_text: Ethyne (C2H2) contains:

options.text: A single bond between carbon atoms
A double bond between carbon atoms
A triple bond between carbon atoms

questions.explanation_correct: Ethyne (acetylene, C2H2) contains a triple bond between the two carbon atoms: H-C triple bond C-H. It is the simplest alkyne. Each carbon is bonded to one hydrogen and shares three pairs of electrons with the other carbon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A single bond (A) would give ethane (C2H6). A double bond (B) would give ethene (C2H4). There must be bonds between the carbons (D is wrong). The formula C2H2 requires a triple bond to satisfy carbon's tetravalency.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an unsaturated hydrocarbon?
questions.explanation_correct: Ethene (C2H4) is an unsaturated hydrocarbon because it contains a carbon-carbon double bond. The formula C2H4 follows CnH2n (alkene formula), whereas methane, ethane, and propane all follow CnH2n+2 (alkane formula) and are saturated.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Methane (A), ethane (B), and propane (C) are all saturated hydrocarbons (alkanes) with only single bonds. Ethene has a C=C double bond, making it unsaturated — it can undergo addition reactions.

questions.question_text: A homologous series is a group of compounds that:

options.text: Differ by -CH2- and have similar chemical properties
Are all isomers of each other

questions.explanation_correct: A homologous series is a family of organic compounds that have the same general formula, share similar chemical properties, and successive members differ by a -CH2- unit (molecular mass difference of 14 u). For example, methane, ethane, propane, butane form the alkane homologous series.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Members of a homologous series have similar (not different) chemical properties (A). They have different molecular formulae (C is wrong). They are not isomers of each other (D) because isomers have the same molecular formula. The defining feature is the constant -CH2- difference.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of the compound with two carbon atoms and one -OH group is:
questions.explanation_correct: Ethanol is the IUPAC name for a compound with two carbon atoms (eth-) and a hydroxyl group (-ol suffix for alcohol). Its formula is C2H5OH or CH3CH2OH. Methanol has one carbon, propanol has three carbons, and ethanal is an aldehyde (not an alcohol).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Methanol (A) has only one carbon atom. Propanol (C) has three carbon atoms. Ethanal (D) has two carbons but contains an aldehyde (-CHO) group, not a hydroxyl (-OH) group. The prefix 'eth-' means two carbons and '-ol' means alcohol.

questions.question_text: The root word 'but-' in IUPAC nomenclature indicates a carbon chain of:
questions.explanation_correct: The root word 'but-' indicates a chain of 4 carbon atoms. The root words for carbon chains are: meth- (1), eth- (2), prop- (3), but- (4), pent- (5), hex- (6), hept- (7), oct- (8), non- (9), dec- (10).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 2 carbons (A) would be 'eth-'. 3 carbons (B) would be 'prop-'. 5 carbons (D) would be 'pent-'. The prefix 'but-' specifically indicates 4 carbon atoms in the longest chain.

questions.question_text: What is the molecular formula of butane?
questions.explanation_correct: Butane is an alkane with 4 carbon atoms. Using the alkane general formula CnH2n+2: C4H2(4)+2 = C4H10. Butane (C4H10) is a commonly used fuel found in LPG (liquefied petroleum gas).
questions.explanation_incorrect: C3H8 (A) is propane (3 carbons). C4H8 (C) would be butene (an alkene). C5H12 (D) is pentane (5 carbons). Butane has 4 carbons and follows the alkane formula CnH2n+2, giving C4H10.

questions.question_text: Two consecutive members of a homologous series differ in molecular mass by:
questions.explanation_correct: Two consecutive members of a homologous series differ by a -CH2- group, which has a molecular mass of 14 u (12 for C + 2 for 2H = 14). For example, methane (CH4, 16 u) and ethane (C2H6, 30 u) differ by 14 u.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 12 u (A) is the mass of one carbon atom only. 16 u (C) is the mass of one oxygen atom. 28 u (D) would be two CH2 units. The exact difference is 14 u because each successive member adds one C (12) and two H (2) atoms.

questions.question_text: The functional group -OH represents:
questions.explanation_correct: The functional group -OH (hydroxyl group) represents the alcohol family. When attached to a carbon chain, it gives the compound the suffix '-ol' in IUPAC naming. Examples: methanol (CH3OH), ethanol (C2H5OH), propanol (C3H7OH).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aldehyde (A) has the -CHO group. Ketone (B) has the >C=O group. Carboxylic acid (D) has the -COOH group. The -OH group specifically identifies alcohols.

questions.question_text: The functional group -COOH represents:
questions.explanation_correct: The functional group -COOH (carboxyl group) represents the carboxylic acid family. The suffix for carboxylic acids in IUPAC naming is '-oic acid'. Examples: methanoic acid (HCOOH), ethanoic acid (CH3COOH).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alcohol (A) has the -OH group. Aldehyde (B) has the -CHO group. Ketone (C) has the >C=O group. The -COOH group, containing both a C=O and an -OH on the same carbon, identifies carboxylic acids.

questions.question_text: Complete combustion of methane (CH4) produces:
questions.explanation_correct: Complete combustion of methane produces carbon dioxide and water: CH4 + 2O2 -> CO2 + 2H2O. In complete combustion (sufficient oxygen), carbon is fully oxidised to CO2 and hydrogen to H2O, along with the release of heat and light energy.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CO + H2O (A) would be the product of incomplete combustion. CO2 + H2 (C) is incorrect — hydrogen forms water. C + H2O (D) is also incomplete combustion. Complete combustion with sufficient oxygen always gives CO2 and H2O.

questions.question_text: An addition reaction is characteristic of:
questions.explanation_correct: Addition reactions are characteristic of unsaturated hydrocarbons (alkenes and alkynes). In an addition reaction, atoms are added across the double or triple bond, converting it to a single or double bond. For example, CH2=CH2 + H2 -> CH3CH3 (ethene to ethane).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Saturated hydrocarbons (A) undergo substitution reactions, not addition. Noble gases (C) are inert. Ionic compounds (D) do not undergo addition reactions. The double/triple bonds in unsaturated hydrocarbons are the sites for addition reactions.

questions.question_text: Substitution reactions are characteristic of:
questions.explanation_correct: Substitution reactions are characteristic of alkanes (saturated hydrocarbons). In a substitution reaction, one atom or group is replaced by another. For example, CH4 + Cl2 -> CH3Cl + HCl (in presence of sunlight), where a hydrogen is replaced by chlorine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alkenes (A) and alkynes (B) primarily undergo addition reactions due to their double/triple bonds. It is not all of the above (D). Alkanes, being saturated with only single bonds, characteristically undergo substitution reactions.

questions.question_text: When ethanol is oxidised with alkaline KMnO4 or acidified K2Cr2O7, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: When ethanol (CH3CH2OH) is oxidised with alkaline potassium permanganate (KMnO4) or acidified potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7), it is converted to ethanoic acid (CH3COOH, acetic acid). The alcohol group (-OH) is oxidised to the carboxylic acid group (-COOH).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethane (A) would be a reduction product. Ethene (B) is formed by dehydration of ethanol, not oxidation. Ethanal (D) is an intermediate but with strong oxidising agents, the final product is ethanoic acid.

questions.question_text: The common name of ethanoic acid is:
questions.explanation_correct: The common name of ethanoic acid (CH3COOH) is acetic acid. It is the main component of vinegar (5-8% solution of acetic acid in water). Acetic acid has a pungent smell and sour taste, and it is used in food preservation and as a laboratory reagent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Formic acid (A) is the common name of methanoic acid (HCOOH). Citric acid (B) is found in citrus fruits. Tartaric acid (D) is found in grapes. Acetic acid is specifically the common name for ethanoic acid.

questions.question_text: Ethanol is commonly known as:
questions.explanation_correct: Ethanol (C2H5OH) is commonly known as grain alcohol or simply alcohol. It is produced by the fermentation of sugars and is found in alcoholic beverages. Wood spirit (methyl alcohol) is methanol, which is highly toxic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wood spirit (A) is methanol (CH3OH), not ethanol. Glycerol (C) is a trihydric alcohol with three -OH groups. Acetone (D) is a ketone (propanone). Ethanol is specifically called grain alcohol because it is obtained by fermenting grains.

questions.question_text: When ethanol reacts with sodium, the products are:
questions.explanation_correct: When ethanol reacts with sodium: 2C2H5OH + 2Na -> 2C2H5ONa + H2. The products are sodium ethoxide and hydrogen gas. Sodium replaces the hydrogen of the -OH group. This reaction is much less vigorous than sodium with water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium ethanoate (A, C) would be the salt of ethanoic acid, not ethanol. Water (C, D) is not produced in this reaction. The reaction produces sodium ethoxide (an alkoxide) and hydrogen gas.

questions.question_text: Denatured alcohol is ethanol mixed with:
questions.explanation_correct: Denatured alcohol is ethanol that has been mixed with small amounts of methanol or other toxic/foul-tasting substances to make it unfit for drinking. This is done for industrial-grade ethanol to prevent its misuse as a beverage, while still being useful as a solvent and fuel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mixing with water (A) would just dilute it. Sugar (C) would not make it unfit for drinking. Acetic acid (D) would make vinegar. Methanol and other poisonous additives specifically denature the alcohol to prevent consumption.

questions.question_text: Vinegar is a dilute solution of:
questions.explanation_correct: Vinegar is a 5-8% aqueous solution of ethanoic acid (acetic acid, CH3COOH). It is widely used in cooking, food preservation (pickling), and as a household cleaning agent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Methanoic acid (A) is formic acid, not found in vinegar. Citric acid (C) is found in citrus fruits. Hydrochloric acid (D) is a mineral acid. Vinegar specifically contains dilute ethanoic acid (acetic acid).

questions.question_text: Ethanoic acid reacts with sodium bicarbonate to produce:
questions.explanation_correct: CH3COOH + NaHCO3 -> CH3COONa + H2O + CO2. Ethanoic acid reacts with sodium bicarbonate to produce sodium acetate (sodium ethanoate), water, and carbon dioxide gas. The brisk effervescence of CO2 is a test for carboxylic acids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: NaCl (A) would require HCl, not ethanoic acid. H2 (C) is produced when acids react with metals, not carbonates. Na2CO3 + CH3COOH (D) lists reactants, not products. The reaction produces sodium ethanoate, water, and CO2.

questions.question_text: The melting point of pure ethanoic acid (glacial acetic acid) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The melting point of pure ethanoic acid is 17 degrees C (290 K). This means it often freezes during cold weather, forming ice-like crystals, which is why pure ethanoic acid is called 'glacial acetic acid' (resembling a glacier).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 0 degrees C (A) is the freezing point of water. 78 degrees C (C) is the boiling point of ethanol. 100 degrees C (D) is the boiling point of water. Glacial acetic acid freezes at 17 degrees C.

questions.question_text: Soaps do not work well in hard water because:

options.text: Soap reacts with calcium/magnesium ions to form scum
Hard water has too much salt

questions.explanation_correct: Soaps do not work well in hard water because the calcium (Ca2+) and magnesium (Mg2+) ions in hard water react with the soap molecules to form insoluble calcium/magnesium salts of fatty acids, known as scum. This scum wastes the soap and does not clean effectively.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Temperature (A) is not the issue. Hard water does not simply dissolve soap (C). The salt content (D) is not the main problem. The specific problem is that Ca2+ and Mg2+ ions react with soap to form an insoluble scum.

questions.question_text: The cleaning action of soap involves the formation of:
questions.explanation_correct: The cleaning action of soap involves the formation of micelles. A micelle is a spherical structure formed when soap molecules arrange themselves with their hydrophobic (non-polar) tails pointing inward (trapping the oily dirt) and hydrophilic (polar) heads pointing outward (toward water). This allows the oily dirt to be washed away.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Emulsions (A) are mixtures of two immiscible liquids — while related, the specific structures formed by soap are called micelles. Crystals (C) and precipitates (D) are not formed during the cleaning action. Micelles are the key structures that enable soap to remove oily dirt.

questions.question_text: Detergents are preferred over soaps because:

options.text: They work in both hard and soft water

questions.explanation_correct: Detergents are preferred over soaps because they work effectively in both hard and soft water. Unlike soaps, detergents do not form insoluble scum with calcium and magnesium ions in hard water. This makes them more versatile and efficient cleaning agents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Detergents are not always cheaper (A). They are synthetic, not natural products (C). Many detergents are actually non-biodegradable, which is an environmental concern (D). The main advantage is their ability to work in hard water.

questions.question_text: Buckminsterfullerene (C60) is an allotrope of carbon with:
questions.explanation_correct: Buckminsterfullerene (C60) has a spherical cage-like structure resembling a football (soccer ball). It consists of 60 carbon atoms arranged in 12 pentagons and 20 hexagons. It was named after the architect Buckminster Fuller who designed geodesic domes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Graphite (A) has a flat layered structure. Diamond (B) has a rigid 3D tetrahedral structure. Amorphous (D) means no definite structure. C60 has a unique hollow spherical structure.

questions.question_text: Hydrogenation of vegetable oils using a nickel catalyst converts them into:
questions.explanation_correct: Hydrogenation of vegetable oils (which contain unsaturated C=C bonds) using a nickel catalyst converts them into saturated fats, commonly known as vanaspati ghee or vegetable ghee. This is an addition reaction where hydrogen adds across the double bonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alcohols (A) are not formed by hydrogenation of oils. Carboxylic acids (C) would require oxidation. Esters (D) are formed by reaction of alcohol with acid. Hydrogenation specifically saturates the double bonds, converting liquid oils to solid fats.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of the compound CH3COCH3 is:
questions.explanation_correct: CH3COCH3 is propanone (commonly known as acetone). It has 3 carbon atoms (prop-) and a ketone functional group (>C=O) in the middle, giving the suffix '-one'. Propanone is the simplest ketone and is widely used as a solvent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Propanal (A) would be CH3CH2CHO (an aldehyde with -CHO group at the end). Propanoic acid (C) would be CH3CH2COOH (with -COOH group). Propanol (D) would be CH3CH2CH2OH (with -OH group). The >C=O group in the middle identifies it as a ketone.

questions.question_text: Unsaturated hydrocarbons decolourise bromine water. This is because they undergo:
questions.explanation_correct: Unsaturated hydrocarbons decolourise bromine water because they undergo addition reactions. Bromine adds across the double or triple bond, converting the unsaturated hydrocarbon to a saturated one. For example, CH2=CH2 + Br2 -> CH2BrCH2Br. This is a standard test for unsaturation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Saturated hydrocarbons undergo substitution (A), not addition. Combustion (C) involves burning. Decomposition (D) involves breakdown. The decolourisation of bromine water is specifically due to an addition reaction with the C=C or C≡C bond.

questions.question_text: Long-term consumption of alcohol damages the:
questions.explanation_correct: Long-term consumption of alcohol (ethanol) primarily damages the liver. The liver is responsible for metabolising alcohol, and excessive consumption leads to conditions like fatty liver, hepatitis, and cirrhosis (permanent scarring of the liver). Alcohol also affects the nervous system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While alcohol affects multiple organs, the primary organ damaged is the liver (not lungs A, kidneys only C, or bones only D). The liver processes alcohol, and chronic overuse leads to severe liver diseases including cirrhosis.

questions.question_text: Carbon can form a maximum of four covalent bonds because it has four valence electrons.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Carbon has an electronic configuration of 2, 4, meaning it has 4 electrons in its outermost shell. It can share each of these 4 electrons with other atoms to form 4 covalent bonds, achieving a stable octet (8 electrons in the outermost shell).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbon's tetravalency (ability to form 4 bonds) is directly related to its 4 valence electrons. Each electron can be shared with another atom to form one covalent bond.

questions.question_text: Alkanes are unsaturated hydrocarbons.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Alkanes are saturated hydrocarbons, not unsaturated. They contain only single bonds between carbon atoms and have the maximum number of hydrogen atoms possible. Alkenes and alkynes are unsaturated hydrocarbons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Alkanes have only single C-C bonds, making them saturated (fully bonded with hydrogen atoms). Unsaturated hydrocarbons are alkenes (double bonds) and alkynes (triple bonds).

questions.question_text: The molecular formula of the third member of the alkane homologous series is C3H8.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The alkane homologous series is: CH4 (methane, 1st), C2H6 (ethane, 2nd), C3H8 (propane, 3rd). Using the general formula CnH2n+2 for n=3: C3H2(3)+2 = C3H8. Propane is the third member.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The first three alkanes are methane (CH4), ethane (C2H6), and propane (C3H8). Using the formula CnH2n+2, the third member (n=3) has the formula C3H8, which is propane.

questions.question_text: Saturated hydrocarbons burn with a clean blue flame while unsaturated hydrocarbons burn with a sooty yellow flame.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Saturated hydrocarbons (like methane and LPG) generally burn with a clean blue flame because they undergo complete combustion. Unsaturated hydrocarbons (like ethyne) tend to burn with a sooty, yellow flame because of incomplete combustion due to their higher carbon content ratio.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The combustion behaviour differs between saturated and unsaturated hydrocarbons. The higher percentage of carbon in unsaturated hydrocarbons leads to incomplete combustion and soot formation, producing a yellow sooty flame.

questions.question_text: Soap molecules have a hydrophilic head and a hydrophobic tail.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Soap molecules have a dual nature: a hydrophilic (water-loving) head which is the ionic/polar part (e.g., -COONa+), and a hydrophobic (water-fearing) tail which is the long hydrocarbon chain. This dual nature allows soap to interact with both water and oily dirt.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Soap molecules are indeed amphiphilic — they have both a polar hydrophilic head and a non-polar hydrophobic tail. This structure is essential for their cleaning action through micelle formation.

questions.question_text: In graphite, each carbon atom is bonded to three other carbon atoms.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. In graphite, each carbon atom is covalently bonded to three other carbon atoms in flat hexagonal layers. The fourth valence electron is free to move between the layers, which is why graphite conducts electricity (an exception among non-metals).
questions.explanation_incorrect: In graphite, carbon forms only 3 bonds with neighbouring carbon atoms (not 4 like in diamond). The remaining electron is delocalised, contributing to graphite's electrical conductivity and soft, layered structure.

questions.question_text: The ability of carbon to form bonds with other carbon atoms forming long chains is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Catenation is the ability of carbon to form strong covalent bonds with other carbon atoms, resulting in long straight chains, branched chains, and ring structures. This property is key to the existence of millions of organic compounds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'catenation'. This unique property of carbon, along with its tetravalency, allows carbon to form an enormous variety of compounds with diverse structures.

questions.question_text: Hydrocarbons containing only single bonds are called ___ hydrocarbons.
questions.explanation_correct: Hydrocarbons containing only single bonds between carbon atoms are called saturated hydrocarbons or alkanes. They are 'saturated' because each carbon is bonded to the maximum possible number of hydrogen atoms. Their general formula is CnH2n+2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'saturated'. Saturated hydrocarbons (alkanes) have no double or triple bonds. When multiple bonds are present, the hydrocarbons are called unsaturated (alkenes or alkynes).

questions.question_text: Successive members of a homologous series differ by a ___ group.
questions.explanation_correct: Successive members of a homologous series differ by a -CH2- group, which corresponds to a molecular mass difference of 14 u (12 for carbon + 2 for hydrogen). This constant difference is a characteristic feature of all homologous series.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is '-CH2-'. Each successive member in a homologous series has one additional -CH2- unit compared to the previous member. For example, methane (CH4), ethane (C2H6), propane (C3H8) each differ by -CH2-.

questions.question_text: The 5-8% aqueous solution of ethanoic acid is known as ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A 5-8% aqueous solution of ethanoic acid (acetic acid) is commonly known as vinegar. It is widely used as a food preservative, in salad dressings, and in pickling. Vinegar has been used by humans for thousands of years.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'vinegar'. This dilute solution of acetic acid in water is one of the most commonly used household chemicals, found in every kitchen.

questions.question_text: The process of adding hydrogen to an unsaturated hydrocarbon in the presence of a catalyst is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Hydrogenation is the process of adding hydrogen (H2) to an unsaturated hydrocarbon in the presence of a catalyst (usually nickel or palladium). This converts the unsaturated compound to a saturated one. For example, vegetable oils are hydrogenated to make vanaspati ghee.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'hydrogenation'. This addition reaction converts double/triple bonds to single bonds by adding hydrogen atoms. It is a commercially important process in the food industry.

questions.question_text: When ethanol is heated with excess concentrated sulphuric acid at 170 degrees C, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: When ethanol is heated with excess concentrated H2SO4 at 170 degrees C, dehydration occurs: C2H5OH -> C2H4 + H2O. Ethene (ethylene) is formed by the removal of a water molecule. H2SO4 acts as a dehydrating agent in this reaction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethane (A) would require reduction, not dehydration. Ethanoic acid (C) would require oxidation. Diethyl ether (D) is formed at a lower temperature (140 degrees C). At 170 degrees C with excess H2SO4, dehydration produces ethene.

questions.question_text: Why does graphite conduct electricity while diamond does not?

options.text: Graphite has free electrons between its layers

questions.explanation_correct: Graphite conducts electricity because each carbon atom uses only 3 of its 4 valence electrons for bonding, leaving one free (delocalised) electron per atom. These free electrons can move between the layers, carrying electric charge. In diamond, all 4 electrons are used in bonding, leaving no free electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Graphite has covalent bonds, not ionic (A). Diamond also has covalent bonds, not metallic (C). Hardness (D) is unrelated to electrical conductivity. The key difference is the presence of free (delocalised) electrons in graphite.

questions.question_text: A soap molecule has a:
questions.explanation_correct: A soap molecule has a hydrophilic (water-loving) head, which is the ionic end (e.g., -COO-Na+), and a hydrophobic (water-fearing) tail, which is the long hydrocarbon chain (e.g., C15H31-). This dual nature enables soap to act as an emulsifying agent between water and oily dirt.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It does not have two hydrophilic ends (A) or two hydrophobic ends (B) — it has one of each. It is not completely non-polar (D) — the head is polar/ionic. The amphiphilic nature (having both polar and non-polar parts) is what makes soap effective as a cleaning agent.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly represents a homologous series?
questions.explanation_correct: CH3OH (methanol), C2H5OH (ethanol), C3H7OH (propanol) form a homologous series of alcohols. Each member differs from the next by a -CH2- unit, they share the same functional group (-OH), and have similar chemical properties. This satisfies all conditions of a homologous series.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A mixes different types (CH4 is alkane, C2H4 is alkene, C3H4 is alkyne). Option C has two members from different series. Option D has three different functional groups (alkane, alcohol, aldehyde). A homologous series must have the same functional group and differ by -CH2-.
